reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s multiplicative ‘product of factors’ model (Sec. 2.4) as allegedly the foundation for eutopian fragility. That model is a meaningful support for the “fragility” intuition, so the attacked claim is somewhat central, but it is not the paper’s entire basis: the argument also leans on historical moral error, many independent candidate ‘single-flaw’ catastrophes, and the later technical discussion of fussy vs easygoing moral views. Strength is limited because (i) the paper presents the multiplicative model explicitly as a toy/illustrative model rather than a required assumption, and (ii) even if value were additive/with redundancy, many of the paper’s examples could still imply large value loss from particular moral errors. The critique is partly correct that the paper does not empirically validate independence/multiplicativity and that alternative aggregation with substitution could weaken the “near-zero from one miss” picture; however it overstates (“entire argument rests”, “mathematically manufacture”) and its empirical claims about substitutability in human flourishing are contestable and not clearly transferable to cross-moral-dimension evaluation. It is clear and focused, with little dead weight.
title: Substitutability among value dimensions undermines the multiplicative fragility model
